reviewText:
A True Free-to-Play GameNo DLCs
No Ingame shops
No packs to buy
No unlockables
All weapons and equipment are available for everyone right from the start!

America's Army: Proving Grounds is a multiplayer only FPS (First-Person Shooter).
The community is friendly, helpful and values teamwork. I've played CS, Battlefield, CoD, Insurgency, Unreal, Homefront, Medal of Honor...You name it! I've played pretty much every competitive FPS out there!
Basically i have tons of experience when it comes to multiplayer gaming and this little hidden gem is my most played multiplayer shooter in the past 2 or 3 years.
The reason ? It's well balanced, the community is friendly and people ALWAYS use the ingame voice chat for teamwork! It's truelly amazing!

How do they manage to keep the game well balanced ? It's quite simple really. The game only has 5 primary weapons: 2 assault rifles (fully automatic and a burst-fire one. Both can be switched to single fire aswell), a sniper rifle, a shotgun and an LMG. All these weapons are available since the very beginning so a rank 30 player has the same weapons as a rank 1 player. The only advantage a higher ranking player can have is the knowledge of map layouts.
You also have a sidearm which is just a pistol but it can come real handy.
You also get one frag grenade and can choose between 2 fog, smoke or flash grenades. Also available from rank 1.

You do gain XP (experience points) with each kill, secure, revive and round/match won or lost and gaining XP helps you rank (level) up. The thing is that ranking up gives you nothing. No new weapons, no new equipment, health bonus, scopes or camos. Ranks only show how much a player has been playing the game. Nothing more.

You start each round with 100% of hp and 1 life. Once you get killed" you cannot respawn untill a teammate revives you. If an enemy player gets to your body first he can secure you and your teammates cannot revive you anymore. In that case you have to wait untill the end of the round to get back into the fight.
Headshots are an instant kill and you cannot be revived from those. Once you get shot you start bleeding out so you have to bandage yourself to stop the bleeding or you may die or just lose a lot of hp (health points).

There are 2 modes: Normal and Hardcore.
Normal mode: You can spot enemies
recommended: teammates have blue names on their heads and you can see downed teammates. In the normal mode you can also see a yellow text that says you killed an enemy. This is disabled in the hardcore mode.\nHardcore mode: There's no spotting enemies

The history in the America's Army series is so great. I downloaded this game a few days after the beta release and played until shortly before official release (roughly 3 years). And I (like many others) participated heavily in the competition community for this game. So it is with a heavy heart that I write this review.

AA:PG was one of those games that started out with a lot of potential. The team of devs behind it seemed eager to take suggestions and even more eager to follow through with what they said would be done. There were serious issues along the way (PB problems, launcher issues, major glitches), but things seemed to get fixed on a regular basis. However, I started noticing a regular pattern. Much like a lot of other games currently on the market, patches were being issued and one thing would get fixed while two to three other elements were being broken because the developer team decided something wasn't quite right. Everytime an update/patch was issued an uproar arose from the community. Casual players were leaving on a regular basis. The community was changing incredibly fast. The one constant in the community was the group of us who competed in this game. Eventually, the dev team got so tired of hearing what the competitive players had to say that they outright told us they would rather we all leave than continue making suggestions for how to iron out the wrinkles in the game. They outed the one portion of the community that only wanted to game to get better. Of course, with an attitude like that, some of the more confident (and toxic) competitive players began following developers around into games and trolling them heavily. This game could have been very good. The idea was there. The attitude was not. The developers clashed with the competition community and that caused this game to fall apart. In almost a **** you this is MY game and I will do what I want with it!" fashion. Now the game is a complete trainwreck and will never work or run the way it should have. I've given up on AA:PG after three years and 5000 hours invested.

TL:DR Game had potential. Developers are ***hats. I wasted 5000 hours of my life. Don't try this game."

OVERVIEWProving grounds is a fast-paced team oriented multiplayer shooter co-developed by the US-Army as a recruiting tool. (does that even work?) The previous games opted for a challenging simulation shooter style whereas this game borrows over elements of both counterstrike as well as call of duty making for an interesting blend of competitive tactical shooter.

Proving grounds is a game that requires teamwork and strategy, much like counterstrike. The scoping, sprinting and prone options feel more like call of duty as well as adding its own unique features such as reviving teammates securing fallen enemies and healing yourself. The modes center around capture the flag, team elimination, and bomb planting.

Its very much a hardcore shooter in that you can die very quickly if you are reckless, and it is very rewarding when you manage to help your team or work together with your clan. If offers 6v6 and 12v12 maps for servers.

PROS+ Nice blend of old and new features
+ Server browser and dedicated servers
+ Can be very competitive
+ Most of the players are older, more mature & very friendly.
+ Free to play

CONS- Hardcore difficulty might not be for everyone
- Is a drastic change from the earlier installments
- Occasional bugs
- Relatively small userbase

BOTTOM LINEIf you like competitive team-based shooters like Counterstrike and Insurgency consider giving this one a try, its free anyway. As always, please like if you enjoyed the review, thanks!

reviewText:
This game is a shooter.It's called America's Army, and you always play as the Americans. In many respects those are the only things that veterans of the AA-AA3 will find solace in. Apart from that this game seems very much a rehashed shooter. However it is well made. The sound is excellent. Once again you can hear the enemies if they are happy to run around making noise giving you cues to where they lurk. The gun shouts are loud and powerful sounding and very quick to make you jump. The visuals are excellent as well, smoke completely blinds you as it seeps around the corners giving you cover.
Why is this an AA game? Because it still calls on the player to use military foundations to win :
1) Teamwork. People must realize this is the reason for online games. Play with your team, not for yourself.
2) Communication. If you don't communicate with your team, you will fail. The community is happy to help you out when you let them know the situation.
3) Tactical superiority. Suppression fire, holding chokepoints and forcing the enemy to play your style to complete the missions.
Even though America's Army: Proving Grounds abandoned many of the previous games features it still has a solid gameplay reminiscent of the better AA titles, tactical movement as per previous titles (leaning, breathing control, revive/secure mechanics), and a highly responsive developer team showing that the AA series is still alive and kicking.

reviewText:
America's Army: Proving Grounds

Updated 12/12/2014.

The game does have some pros, but these are far outweighed by the cons.

Positives:

+ Free download, no cost whatsoever.
+ Graphical improvements compared to America's Army 3. The game looks a fair bit better but it's still not anything amazing.
+ Really interesting United States army recruitment videos, showing you how they train and the opportunities that exist while serving.
+ More options for weapon selection. The developers have listened to player feedback from America's Army 3. You now carry a secondary firearm (pistol), along with one primary weapon, either a sniper rifle, M249 SAW, standard issue rifle or a shotgun.
+ There's a nice mix of maps available, keeping the game fresh.
+ Hardcore mode. Thank goodness they implemented this into the game. The problem is, nobody uses it, probably because they would all suck if they did (lol). There's not many servers for hardcore mode. It erases the stupid features which make the game less strategy oriented, like enemies being marked on your map and unlimited medical revives for teammates. You can actually bleed out from wounds, similar to America's Army 3. However, hardcore mode doesn't solve the inherent flaws in gameplay, such as the bad shooting and lack of teamwork. Ideally, it should have been the default mode for the game. As you'll see from my negatives below, the main game mode which has been coined 'user friendly', is atrocious and should never have been released.

Negatives:

- The main game mode for America's Army: Proving Grounds is less skill based and more generic than America's Army 3. It follows in the footsteps of mainstream First Person Shooter titles, which are not focused on teamwork.
- The main game mode is much more unrealistic than America's Army 3. If you're shot in the legs or arms, it doesn't affect your ability to run or aim steadily. You can be on 1% health in America's Army: Proving Grounds and still sprint around, jump onto objects and shoot the enemy as if nothing ever happened. It's simply ridiculous.
- You can now medic yourself using bandages an infinite number of times. Have you been shot? No problem, just heal yourself. Have you been shot again? No worries, just heal yourself. Were you shot a third time? No problem, just heal again. I don't know what clown came up with this idea. The only way to die in the main game mode is to be secured by an enemy team member (which involves them pressing a key while standing above you). If you're shot in the head you can still be revived if you haven't been secured, lol.

- It's extremely difficult to locate enemy soldiers who are firing on you, this is because of the poor visual game design and colours used. It's a frustrating chore.
- The maps in America's Army: Proving Grounds are complex, which you would think is a benefit to the game. Alas, this negatively impacts upon player interaction and teamwork. America's Army 3 was successful due to the small map sizes, which were easy to adapt to and understand. This fostered teamwork, where players stuck together and fought to control important areas. Because the maps were straightforward, most players were able to provide detailed intelligence on enemy locations. America's Army: Proving Grounds suffers from large maps, where a great number of individuals have no idea how to tell their team where the enemy is. There is very limited exchange of conversation on microphone, which is a shame.
- The shooting is bad, it really is. The guns are inaccurate and annoying. Weapons from America's Army 3 were not precise either, but they were reliable and could hit targets.
- The game is boring, what can I say? It's not fun at all, unlike America's Army 3. Many of the best players I know from America's Army 3 consistently die in this game now, myself included. Sure, they're still better than other players, but the game doesn't reward them for playing tactically.

Overall Score: 3.5/10

I've played America's Army 3 in excess of 1,000 hours and I'm experienced with the gameplay. It was the only First Person Shooter I've truly enjoyed. America's Army: Proving Grounds destroys the series and is a pure embarrassment, one that has sadly resulted in the end of my America's Army career.

In the end I wrote this review, In the end I removed the game from my computer (After this review)

In the end.

reviewText: America's Army: Proving Grounds isn't exactly anything you haven't seen before, yet, at the same time, is still a pretty great game, expecially when you consider that this game is currently in BETA. Using the Unreal Engine 3 was a noble move, making the load times excellent, the graphics average, and the controls responsive, but what really got my attention was the sound. At one time, when I heard a Russian voice coming out of an in-game intercom behind my character, I actually looked around the room I was sitting in, for the sound was THAT realistic. Although most ascpects of this title are either average or superb, there was one problem: Server balancing. This isn't exactly a problem with the actual game, but it can be INCREDIBLY annoying when you find yourself up against 8 other players. For a BETA project, America's Army: Proving Grounds puts other F2PFPS's to shame, but if it were a finished project, I wouldn't reccomend it to everbody. That said, however, AA:PG is still a BETA, and that is why I'm giving this Tactical Shooter a 9.0 out of 10, a near perfect score, a winner of a gold medal, and the winner of a spot in my top 20 favorite F2P games of all time. (As of 2014.)

reviewText:
OVERVIEW

America's Army: Proving Grounds is a decent, free, arcade/sim mix FPS. Unfortunately, it was much better in beta than in its full release, which was in October of 2015. Considering it is now early May and nothing has been fixed, I cannot recommend this game.

PROS
+ It's free.
+ You can't play the bad guys in this game; no matter which team you're on, you look like the Americans, and the other team looks like the enemy. However, you're, in reality, both on the same side, and this is a training exercise. Excellent worldview.
+ All of the soldiers are male.
+ No bad content (such as profanity) in the game itself.

CONS
- The sound in the full release is absolutely horrible. Footsteps can be very difficult to make out, if you hear them at all.
- I think the graphics are a bit too dark in the full release. I preferred beta's.
- The tutorial and other practice rounds should be more comprehensive, and there should be more of them. E.g., you should have a level where you can practice takedowns. The Giunta Weapon Range has also been made inferior since beta, with it giving you long range targets even when using, say, a shotgun, and it not having all weapons and all scopes.
- Co-op versus AI existed in at least one past AA game, and would make a fun addition here, too, I think.
- Performance could be improved. While it runs fine for me, a lot of people with good PCs have performance issues they shouldn't be having. Very large ones.
- A more tactical approach would be better. For instance, supported is a bit OP (and really glitchy, which is the main problem).
- New maps are getting progressively worse in terms of performance (FPS) and realism/tactical design. They're extremely open and full of noob hiding spots. Coldfront and Slums are excellent examples of outdoor maps...Homestead, Stone Ruins, Cabin Fever, and Overload are all jokes.
- VIP mode? Nope. Medic system (though I wouldn't mind getting rid of revives, period)? Neg. Any new features? Nonexistent. The dev team has been immensely unimpressive in every area imaginable.

This is my first Online multiplayer FPS experience, and it's mostly been good. However, the game itself has been ruthlessly murdered by the developers. Just reverting back to beta would make the game much better. Do that, add VIP mode, make the game more realism/comp oriented, and we'd be golden. Sadly, it's not looking like that's going to happen.

Rest in peace, beta. You were beautiful and I loved you. Oh, what you could have become.

Rest in peace, indeed.

reviewText:
Here we go. My review of AA:PG beta:
This game is a tactical first person shooter. If I had to compare it to Counter Strike, and Call of Duty(worst game ever, btw, don't buy). It has elements of both games, however it leans more toward CS on terms of game mechanics.
Pros:
+It's free to play - if it's free it's worth the money, duh.
+The community is very kind, for the most part. Most players are 18+ and very kind.
+Pretty good looking on terms of graphics. Better than Call of Duty :D
+Maps are well designed.
+The workshop has many maps avalable for free download
+Actually taught me a thing of two about the Army
+replayability

Cons:
+Lack of weapons, hopefully they'll add more..
+The menu navigation can be a bit more difficult than other games.
+No depth/lore
+Not noob friendly.. At all. - You've gotta learn before you can live
+Could be more optimized
+I know this is probably whining, but WHY THE FK CAN YOU ONY JUMP 2 CENTIMETERS AND TAKE 7 TRILLION DAMAGE WHEN FALLIN A METER?

Conclusion:
It's pretty good and it's free. The one twist, however, is that it's hard. Also, if you're looking for a good story in a game - don't look here, you won't find it. The thing that I think makes this game special is some of the people you will find. Instead of ♥♥♥♥♥ey little kids, you will meet adults who are kind and welcoming! All together it's a fun experience. Especially if you're good at FPS game. Finally, a thing to remember, this is a TEAM game. You must cooperate with your team mates or you're going to die a lot.

4. (Post-release) Colors: The colors have become grittier, and more CODish, the once vibrant landscape is now a pain to look at.

Final Score: 37/100

reviewText:
I had a difficult time deciding whether or not I would recommend this game. Here's why:

PROS:
-this game is completely free of charge (aside from tax payer funding), without any micro-transaction gimmicks.
-everyone has access to the same equipment: nothing to unlock (no training missions like that of AA3)
-integrated voice communication
-reasonable graphics, although the optimization leaves much to be desired
-decent map design. There are a good number of maps, but servers tend to replay only a handful of them.
-very mature community, although I was once accused of being a hacker.

CONS:
-there is NO squad mechanic within the game. Isn't an America's Army title supposed to encourage teamwork? After all, this game is a recruiting tool. It would serve its purpose better if it instilled a sense of comradery, which is not what happened. Even America's Army 3 had some form of a squad mechanic, where loadouts were divided amongst fireteams.
-buggy/glitchy: I have had my rank reset to zero at times... or getting stuck in a wall after a revive
-sound design is a hit or miss. The sound of rounds hitting close to you is quite intense, but firing your weapon is the complete opposite. If you try the game, you'll see what I'm talking about.

CONCLUSION:
Although this game does punish run-and-gun" behavior
date: there is no real incentive to cooperate as a cohesive unit. It is leaning towards the "call-of-duty" style of gameplay (AKA one man army). Often you will be bested by a single exceptional player rather than superior team-based tactics.\nBased on your preferred style of playing

seen a bunch of good reviews for this game, but they don't hold true.
the game doesn't appear to be much visually, yet the tax on processing power is substantially high.
it's granulated, as other games were back in the day too - though the resolution of the textures seems to be a small bump up & it certainly doesn't explain the lower frames per second.
as far as pixel colors & the number of total colors being rendered, you should be able to see for yourself the count is low.
blacklight retribution might be a good example of high color count, but it's more spectral than it is solids.
that game runs faster minus the absurd map loading hiccups.
i don't know if there's too much going on in a single thread or if there's too many threads or if there's too many processes.
doesn't seem streamlined as far as programming goes, especially when you can turn off the two light options in the video settings & the frames per second are lower rather than go up.

okay enough about the somewhat(s)?

all the game modes i played won't allow you to respawn after losing, not until the next round.

you make a mistake & lose, then you've got to wait for the next round & there's no guarantee you'll run into the same player.
as relaxed as that sounds (recessed really), the statement is clear. this game is for those that put a lot of stress onto themselves, or those that simply ignore such stress.

The America`s Army series was probably my first real meetup with the FPS genre. I have memories of me playing these games way back in time, and I throughly enjoyed it back then. -Map designs are great
-Animations and models are fantastic

Cons:
-Gets boring

-Not enough developer support
